bestBHT.bht: Paul's commitment to a blameless life is motivated by his hope in the resurrection. He exercises himself, diligently striving for a conscience void of offense towards God and man alike. His deep belief in the reality of the last resurrection and the final judgment propels him to live a life of self-discipline, continually practicing and exercising his faith. Paul's unwavering pursuit of pleasing God and avoiding stumbling is a testament to his genuine and living faith in action.

Henry Alford: 16. herein] accordingly, i.e. ‘having and cherishing this hope.’ I also, i.e. ‘as well as they’
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And herein—On this account, accordingly; that is, looking forward to that awful day."
I exercise myself—The 'I' here is emphatic; 'Whatever they do, this is my study.'"
These are the great principles of my life and conduct—how different from turbulence and sectarianism!
Albert Barnes: To have always a conscience ... - To do what is right, so that my conscience shall never reproach me." (15 words)
To have such a conscience implies two things: Toward God and Toward men." (14 words)
The great and noble aim of Paul was to be pure; and no slander of his enemies, no trials, persecutions, perils, or pains of dying could take away the approving voice of conscience." (31 words)
Marvin Vincent: Exercise myself [ασκω]...hence, to practice, exercise, discipline; and so, in ecclesiastical language, to mortify the body."
The word is used thus in a passive sense here, as in Philippians 1:10.
John Calvin: There is no sharper prick to prick men forward, with all desire to lead a godly and holy life, than the hope of the last resurrection..."
An evil conscience is as good as a thousand witnesses to accuse − men of blockishness, that they may gather for a certainty that they do not earnestly and thoroughly believe eternal life..."
...those do indeed hope for the last resurrection who are never weary of well-doing.
Philip Schaff: The rule of his life was to struggle to keep himself from sin.
Paul's belief... was anything but a merely speculative, it was a real and living faith.
He lived, or rather tried to live, as though he believed, and taught others to do the same.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul claims to be equal to his accusers in efforts to please God.
It [the word 'void of offence'] is a privative and προσκοπτω (to cut or stumble against)... hence the word here appears in both senses.
Certainly his conscience acquitted him of having caused any offence to his countrymen.
John Gill: The apostle studied, and laboured, and bent himself, and employed his thought, care, and time, to have always a conscience void of offence toward God and toward man.

By a 'conscience void of offence', is meant a good conversation; which as it respects God, lies in a carefulness not to offend him, but to do his will; and as it respects men, a shunning what may give offence, or be a stumbling to them.

Though this cannot be perfectly attained to in each of its branches, yet there is in every good man a concern to have such a conscience; and the consideration of the resurrection of the dead, the general judgment, and a future state, induce him to it.
John Wesley: For this cause — With a view to this, I also exercise myself - As well as they.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul declares that his hope in the resurrection of the dead is the driving force behind his actions and mindset. He diligently strives to maintain a conscience that is free from offense to both God and man. Paul's deep commitment to living a blameless life is rooted in his unwavering belief in the reality of the last resurrection and the final judgment. He recognizes that a clear conscience serves as a powerful motivator for godly and holy living. Therefore, Paul actively engages in self-discipline, constantly practicing and exercising his faith in order to remain steadfast in fulfilling God's will and avoiding anything that may cause offense or stumble others. In this way, Paul aims to be equal to his accusers, demonstrating his wholehearted pursuit of pleasing God.

Paul's commitment to a blameless life is motivated by his hope in the resurrection. He exercises himself, diligently striving for a conscience that is free from offense towards God and man alike. His deep belief in the reality of the last resurrection and the final judgment propels him to live a life of self-discipline, continually practicing and exercising his faith. Paul's unwavering pursuit of pleasing God and avoiding stumbling is a testament to his genuine and living faith in action.

Paul explains that his hope in the resurrection drives him to live a life guided by a clear conscience. His unwavering commitment to pleasing God and avoiding offense towards others is grounded in the belief in the final judgment and a future state. Paul actively practices and disciplines himself, aiming to have a conscience void of offense. He recognizes that this diligent pursuit is essential in living out his faith and setting an example for others to do the same.

He diligently strives to maintain a conscience that is free from offense to both God and man. Paul's deep commitment to living a blameless life is rooted in his unwavering belief in the reality of the last resurrection and the final judgment. He recognizes that a clear conscience serves as a powerful motivator for godly and holy living. Therefore, Paul actively engages in self-discipline, constantly practicing and exercising his faith in order to remain steadfast in fulfilling God's will and avoiding anything that may cause offense or stumble others. In this way, Paul aims to be equal to his accusers, demonstrating his wholehearted pursuit of pleasing God.

Paul's commitment to a blameless life is motivated by his hope in the resurrection. He exercises himself, diligently striving for a conscience void of offense towards God and man alike. His deep belief in the reality of the last resurrection and the final judgment propels him to live a life of self-discipline, continually practicing and exercising his faith. Paul's unwavering pursuit of pleasing God and avoiding stumbling is a testament to his genuine and living faith in action.
